name: Garage Rock
description: Raw and energetic, generally employing simple, sloppy, and fuzzbox-distorted guitar melodies in addition to frequent shouting or screaming.

children.name: Frat Rock
children.description: Early form of Garage Rock with hard Rhythm & Blues grooves, catchy melodies, and a "fratty" focus on partying and girls.

children.name: Freakbeat
children.description: Outgrowth of the Mod movement which combines elements of British Rhythm & Blues and Beat with studio effects common in Psychedelia such as fuzztones, flanging and chorus; often seen as a British relative of the American Garage Psych scene.

children.name: Garage Psych
children.description: Emerged from mid-1960s US Garage Rock; characterised by fuzz guitars, cheap organs, experimentation with psychedelic effects and surreal lyricism, and a retained emphasis on raw energy and the pop song format.

children.name: Garage Punk
children.description: Combination of the raw fuzztones of the original Garage Rock bands of the 1960s with the tempo and attitude of Punk Rock.

children.name: Garage Rock Revival
children.description: Incorporated the raucous spirit of '60s Garage Rock into the sensibilities of Alternative Rock and Indie Rock; predominant in the '00s.
